awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Decoding the Enigmas of U.S. Seismic Hazard Via Multi-Scale, Multi-Physics Approaches to Paleoliquefaction Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project will contribute knowledge that reduces the uncertainty of seismic hazards in the United States, thereby promoting scientific progress and the nation's prosperity and welfare.  Nationally, there are many regions in which seismic hazards are especially uncertain because the return periods of earthquakes are longer than the historic record.  In other words, it is known that earthquakes have and will continue to occur, but because prior earthquakes predate human records and/or the advent of seismic instruments, the expected characteristics of future earthquakes are highly uncertain.  In these locales, soil liquefaction caused by past earthquakes, termed "paleoliquefaction," may provide the only evidence from which information about the seismic-hazard can be determined, including earthquake magnitudes, locations, and recurrence-rates.  As a result, U.S. building codes are heavily influenced by paleoliquefaction evidence, and in turn, so too is public safety.  This award supports fundamental research to improve the analysis of paleoliquefaction, which at present suffers from limitations that can lead to highly erroneous results.  The findings will not only advance paleoliquefaction analytics, but will also benefit the understanding of liquefaction hazards in general, thus further reducing earthquake impacts on the built and natural environments.  In addition, an educational research component will investigate links between seismic risk perception and socio-psychological bias, leading to more effective educational platforms in natural hazards engineering. 

This CAREER project aims to remove ubiquitous barriers to the accurate inverse-analysis of paleoliquefaction, which will be achieved by bridging fundamental knowledge-gaps at three distinct scales.  The research includes: (1) micro-scale physical-numerical investigation of the mechanics controlling the formation and morphology of fluidized dikes and sand boils; (2) meso-scale formulation of a coupled, mechanically-consistent liquefaction triggering and manifestation model; and (3) a macro-scale approach to probabilistically geolocate seismic sources from paleoliquefaction and assess their rupture magnitudes.  An analytical framework developed from the fundamental research will then be applied to paleoliquefaction evidence in regions where enigmatic seismic-hazards significantly impact society.  These include the Cascadia Subduction Zone of the Northwest U.S.; the New Madrid Seismic Zone of the Central U.S.; the South Carolina Coastal Plain of the Eastern U.S.; and Coastal New England in the Northeast U.S.  Aided by physical and numerical multi-scale modeling, field testing, and unprecedented case-history data, this research will advance both paleoliquefaction analytics and the understanding of liquefaction hazards in general, thus reducing future earthquake impacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Seismic hazards in many U.S. regions remain uncertain because earthquakes often recur over periods longer than recorded history. Without prior instrumental or human records, the characteristics of future earthquakes, and their impacts, are difficult to predict. In these regions, soil liquefaction from past earthquakes, known as "paleoliquefaction," offers crucial evidence for estimating earthquake magnitudes, locations, and recurrence rates. Paleoliquefaction and other "paleoseismic" relics play a key role in shaping U.S. building codes and ultimately, the nation's welfare and prosperity. This award supported research to improve inverse-analysis of paleoliquefaction and other paleoseismic evidence, addressing limitations that can lead to inaccurate results. The findings will also greatly enhance predictions of liquefaction hazards in future earthquakes, reducing their impact on infrastructure and the environment.

With respect to intellectual merit, the project advanced the understanding and prediction of earthquake ground motions and soil liquefaction's occurrence and consequences at both site-specific and broad regional scales. These gains were driven by improved characterization of geomaterials using both in-situ and remote sensing measurement and by improved understanding of the processes that lead to liquefaction triggering, its surficial manifestation, and its preservation in the geologic record. A probabilistic framework was conceived, validated, and applied for reconstructing past earthquake-source locations, magnitudes, fault geometries, and the resulting ground motions from paleoseismic evidence. This framework was successfully applied to soil liquefaction, landslides, and felt-intensity data, which are each capable of preserving information about past earthquakes, and thus, future seismic hazards. Collectively, these advances have yielded valuable insights into the earthquake sources responsible for, and the impacts of, the 1700 Cascadia Subduction Zone and 1886 Charleston earthquakes, which threaten the Pacific Northwest and South Carolina Coastal Plain, respectively. Additionally, the project investigated how socio-psychological biases influence geohazard risk perception in university students, aiming to improve natural hazards education and communication.

The project's broader impacts are evident in its contributions to public safety, education, and advancements in earthquake engineering and science. Findings will better inform U.S. seismic hazard maps and building codes, reducing earthquake risks to communities and infrastructure. Novel geospatial models developed during the project and driven by machine learning allow for rapid, regional predictions of liquefaction impacts, aiding disaster preparedness, response, and recovery. Educational outreach included K-12 activities, public signage, and participation in STEM events like Engineering Discovery Days. These initiatives raised awareness about earthquake risks and inspired interest in STEM fields. The project produced data and tools for the broader research community. Significant datasets included 15,000+ global liquefaction case histories and 400 cone penetration tests in the Cascadia region. Open-source software tools were developed to analyze subsurface data and predict liquefaction and are available for engineers and scientists nationwide. Partnerships with organizations like the U.S. Geological Survey amplified the project's impact, enabling extensive field testing and data collection. Results have been widely disseminated through journal publications, conference presentations, and public databases. Beyond technical advancements, the research improved public understanding of earthquake hazards and contributed to enhanced resilience. By reducing uncertainties in seismic hazard assessments, the project bolstered public safety and informed policies that protect the built environment.

Select, key project achievements include: (i) improved models for characterizing subsurface materials via in-situ and remote sensing measurements; (ii) improved models for predicting liquefaction occurrence and consequence; (iii) novel frameworks for paleoseismic inverse-analysis, more explicitly accounting for uncertainties and enabling more accurate reconstruction of past earthquakes; (iv) improved understanding of the 1700 Cascadia and 1886 Charleston earthquakes and their impacts; (v) creation of accessible datasets, tools, and software that support ongoing research and practice in earthquake engineering and science; and (vi) engagement of diverse audiences through education, dissemination, and outreach activities, fostering a greater understanding of seismic and geohazard risks.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2024
Modified by: Brett Maurer
